Alarms.Alarm Summary: Multiple hosts are unable to reach 10.1.0.2 (100% packet loss), while remote-worker cannot reach any hosts (100% packet loss to all targets).
Alarms.Recommended Actions:
[
  "Verify the network connectivity and interface status on 10.1.0.2 using the command: show interfaces.",
  "Check the routing table on 10.1.0.2 and relevant routers with: show ip route.",
  "Ensure that 10.1.0.2 is powered on and properly connected to the network.",
  "Check for any firewall rules or ACLs blocking ICMP traffic to 10.1.0.2: show access-lists.",
  "Review recent configuration changes on 10.1.0.2 and associated network devices.",
  "If 10.1.0.2 is a server or endpoint, verify its local firewall settings and network configuration.",
  "Restart the network service or interface on 10.1.0.2 if necessary.",
  "If the issue persists, escalate to the network administrator for further investigation."
]
Alarms.Tracking Next Steps: Monitor the connectivity to 10.1.0.2 from client1, client2, and server by periodically running ping tests to verify if packet loss persists. If the issue remains after recommended troubleshooting, escalate to the network team with details of persistent 100% packet loss to 10.1.0.2 from all internal hosts. For remote-worker, monitor connectivity to all internal IPs and escalate if 100% packet loss continues, as this may indicate broader network or VPN issues.

Alarms.Insights: All devices are unable to reach 10.1.0.2 (100% packet loss), while client1, client2, and server can successfully ping other internal IPs (10.0.2.10, 10.0.3.10, 10.0.4.10) with 0% packet loss. The remote-worker cannot reach any internal IPs (100% packet loss to all). This suggests that 10.1.0.2 is unreachable from the internal network, possibly down or blocked, and the remote-worker is isolated from the internal network.
